clarifying: Clarifiers work best when they name the missing detail.
Specific > broad. Anchor your question to a word, step, or claim.
The best clarifiers point to exactly what's unclear.
Effective clarifying reduces uncertainty for everyone involved.
probing: Great probes surface assumptions and trade-offs.
The magic of 'why' questions: they reveal underlying logic.
Probing works best when it uncovers hidden factors.
Strong probes help people think through their reasoning.
follow_up: Follow-ups show you're listening and want to understand more.
Build on what was just shared rather than changing direction.
The best follow-ups extend the conversation naturally.
comparative: Contrasting options helps clarify decision criteria.
Good comparisons highlight unique strengths and weaknesses.
open_question: Open questions invite creativity and exploration.
The best open questions encourage expansive thinking.
Wide-open questions often yield surprising insights.

clarity.5: Your question is crystal clear - anyone could understand exactly what you're asking for.
clarity.4: Strong clarity - your question targets a specific area with minimal ambiguity.
clarity.3: Decent clarity, but could be more specific about what you need to know.
clarity.2: Somewhat vague - it's unclear which part specifically needs explanation.
clarity.1: Very unclear - too broad or confusing to know how to respond effectively.

depth.5: Excellent depth - your question digs into underlying factors and invites rich exploration.
depth.4: Good depth - goes beyond surface level to explore important aspects.
depth.3: Moderate depth - touches on some important elements but could go deeper.
depth.2: Shallow - stays at surface level without exploring underlying factors.
depth.1: No depth - asks for simple repetition without advancing understanding.

relevance.5: Perfectly relevant - directly addresses the core issue that matters most.
relevance.4: Highly relevant - focuses on important aspects of the situation.
relevance.3: Generally relevant but could target more critical elements.
relevance.2: Somewhat off-track - misses the main point or priority.
relevance.1: Not relevant - doesn't address the actual problem or situation.

empathy.5: Shows excellent awareness of others' perspectives and demonstrates genuine care.
empathy.4: Good empathy - considers how others might feel or be affected.
empathy.3: Some empathy shown, but could better consider others' viewpoints.
empathy.2: Limited empathy - focuses mainly on your own needs without considering others.
empathy.1: No empathy - completely ignores how others might be affected or feel.
